page.lettertext:
fol.169r
May it please yo
r
good L. So longe absence of
e Deputies of
Guel-
derland
and
Overissell
is greatly wondred at heere, and till all the Depu-
ties be mette they can take no resolution upon my proposition. It is
feared very much that some alteration of thinges at home hath stayed
there commyng or at
e least there p
r
sent passinge by reason of
e great
inundations in sundrie places of those Provinces as
e like was never
seene of
e rivers and land waters, in
e memory of any, for all
e
Bettue, and Bommels wert are overflowen and a great
te of
e
Country round about
Utrecht
and
Amersfort,
in so much that the very gate
of
e Towne of Amersfort the suurbes of
vianen,
and many dorpes
and villages, are caried cleane away and multitudes of people to the
number it is thought, of 3000 soules are drowned. And the like is re-
ported of the land above
Collen
where the waters ar risen higher
by sixe foote then hath bene hitherto knowne by any recorde, w
ch
is
supposed to proceed of
e great abondance of raine and snowe
t
hath
fallen in these and in
e upper Cuntryes and of
e long continuance
of these boystrous winds at west w
ch
hath forced the ryvers to swel[l]
out of measure. I find by confferring w
th
some of
e scotti
sh
nation
t
they are informed out of
Scotland
t
Colonell Stuart
is enjoyned by some secret instruction to sollicite
e states for 1000 foote
and 500 horse for sixe monethes or rather for
e loane of so much
mony, as may serve for the levies of so many men requesting
3 monethes paye to be delivered out of hand w
ch
is im
ted unto me
by such persons of credit, as I in my conceipt have reason to believe
it neverthelesse the Coronell him self will not notefie so much as
onely to me but as farre as I perceive to none of
e states proposing
all as yet in generall tearmes and reserving for themselves, to yeald
what succor they thinke best w
ch
is thought to be done, upon a hope
t
he hath,
t
they, of them selves will offer more, then he hath in h[and]
to presse them unto. For mine owne parte the more
t I consider of
his imployment hither and of
e qualitie of his message,
e more methinks
it doth tend to some dessigne to be disliked. For in proceeding w
th
e
Provinces,
the
Kinge
hath gone by such degrees to winne upon that [.]
as I feare some what els, then this purpose p
r
tended of joyninge in al[li-]
ance, and of craving there assistance. If yo
r
L. call to minde in
Feb
r
last was two yeares, the States were moved by Stuart
fol.169v
being sent by the King to intertaine from time to time a reciprocall
intelligence in all affaires,
t
should concerne the religion and weale
of his and their countries, w
ch
was p
nt
ly obtained. They were after
sought unto to renue
e ancient league,
t
had bene in former times
betwene Scotland and them. wherunto they yeelded by there deputies
at
e time of
e Baptisme of
e yonge
Prince,
Now th[irdly] they
ar intreated to assist him w
th
men or mony wherof the summe is
so small not amounting to 8000
li
sterling, for 3 monethes as he might
very well presume
t
they wold not refuse him, and when this shalbe ac-
corded, whether it be not to be thought,
t
he hath yet an intention, to
give some further footing in their love and affection, and to serve some
other turnes w
th
their aide and support, as his occasions shall require
and as it will be verie easie when
e people of these Cuntries ar once
engaged in his actions I leave it as a motion to yo
r
L. wisdome.
The Coronell pretendeth,
t
e state of
e Kinge must be p
nt
ly relieved, and
if
yt
should be neglected, by his frendes, by his frendes, and allies, it wold
engender, ere be long some unreparable inconvenience, both to him
and to them. And this he doth inculcat in everie company where
he commeth w
th
a fearfull declaration of
e wantes of
e K. and of
e strength of his enemies in so much as
e states by
t
as I can
gather wold willingly doe for him if my answere unto them whereof
yo
r
L. had notice in one from me of
e 22 of
e laste not stoppe
there proceeding. For so
e Coronel, hath told me,
t
he thought
e
states resolution wold depend very much upon her High
es
allowance
or onely upon me
t
if I wold signifie,
t
her High
es
wold be
pleased w
th
their aiding of the King there wold be no stoppe, and he
saw no just cause for me to be scrupulous, sith every man might see
the extreamitie of
e King, and
t
part of
e benefitt wold redound
unto her Ma
tie
and all the burden of
e aide, upon the people of these
Provinces. I will not troble yo
r
L. w
th
long rehersall of my
answeres and other speeches betweene us, but in effecte they were
to pray him to pardon my refusall unles my warrant were bette
r
forsaid I to speake of matters roundly, and familiarly between
us, I may very well p
r
sume upon
e reasons you alleage,
t
her
Ma
tie
wold be willing to advance
e K. desire, but yet it may be
perhaps,
t
she will soe much mislike of his terme of proceeding as
fol.170r
wold have the states made acquainted w
th
her manifold endevors to free
the K. of his trobles. Let it be as you give out
t
as his state is reduced
to pointes of extremity, wherof I knowe very litle either one way or
other) though there be
t
will avouch
t
both his perill is not such
and
t
it mought have bene lesse if he him selfe had listed how can
yo
w
reporte it here but they will p
nt
ly aske
e question why
e K.
having so largely and so long tasted of her
Ma
ties
Bountie and the
daunger being nearer, to
England
then to them, he shold not rather in
this case have recourse, unto her High
es
or at
e lest [.]
Prince, and request her advise before he sente to move
e States.
In yo
r
answere hereunto I know not how yo
w
will acquite yo
r
selfe
but yo
w
must wthout offense give me leave to suspecte
t
yo
w
will
speake very litle in her Ma
ties
behalfe but rather secretly com-
plaine in
e maneging of yo
r
businesse
t
she hath not or will not
doe
e part of a neighbor w
ch
may be so amplified in places wher
yo
u
come as I doubte it may also tende to
e
worke some alienation
in
e hartes of this people from there devotion to her High
es
and
these are suche suspicions or causes of suspicions as they force me to
forbeare and not to meddle of or on unles I had co
m
ission. [.]
onely as before I wish the states in these proposals to hold a sound
correspondence by advising w
th
her High
es
.
As a man touched neere and guiltie as it semed of some sinister
dealing (wherof I heare but to much he made a frivolous reply,
full of speeches at randon: w
ch
not being worthy of yo
r
L. reading
I leave unrehersed, very humbly beseching
t
if yo
u
thinke it expe-
dient I may knowe by yo
r
direcc
o
n what course I must ob-
serve when I speake in these affaires to give her Ma
tie
good con-
tent. I find by a l
re
written by
e
F
r
K.
to
Mons
r
Bu-
zanval
t
he hath sent her Ma
tie
certaine l
re
s intercepted
w
ch
were written in Cypher by
Father Gordon
and an other
Scott to their correspondents in
Spaine
w
ch
e K. had caused to
be decyphred. Gordon is one
t
is often named in
Cryttons
latin
l
re
w
ch
I sent yo
r
L. last I shold conjecture,
at
e notice
of such amatter as he hath written into Spaine, may easely
leade to decipher
e l
re
s of Critton in Latin w
ch
if it be not done
already, if yo
r
L. thinke it fitte to sende me
e copie of Gordons
l
re
and
e others, I will do my best endevo
r
to discover
t
of
Critton w
ch
I do very much presume upon certaine conjecture
containe important matters as the conferring of some princely
fol.170v
Copie de la l
re
de M
r
Bodley a M
r
le grand Tresorer, mars 1594
princely state or dignitie, or contrey, upon some speciall person
upon whom the chief hope of those fugitives dependeth wherin it
also seemeth
t
certaine great personages ar nominated
astors
.
And thus &c.
